author: By Declan Walsh and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: The Fight to Lead Kenya: ‘Hustler Nation’ vs. Allied Scions
description: Kenyans vote for a new president on Tuesday, ending a heated race that shows why, in a troubled region, the East African nation matters more than ever.
content: KANGARI, Kenya — The helicopter swooped over the lush tea and coffee fields flanking Mount Kenya, Africa’s second highest peak, and touched down outside a small highland town where William Ruto, the self-proclaimed leader of Kenya’s “hustler nation,” stepped out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Place to Get a Smoothie
description: Byron Walden is here to make you furrow your brow.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Byron Walden is a prolific weekend constructor; we last solved a puzzle of his on a Sunday in April, and this is his 66th Saturday grid. You can count on a thicket of debuts — 12 today — and clues that will make you do a double take, or triple take, or even need to take a break to think things over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of Aug. 1, 2022.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Hey, Joe, Don’t Give It a Go
description: Rest on your laurels, and don’t run for re-election, Mr. President.
content: WASHINGTON — Ruth Bader Ginsburg is a cautionary tale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: How New York City Hopes to Win Its Long, Losing War on Trash
description: Can social media and rat-resistant receptacles help clean up the city?
content: “Did you get that?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How a Couple Who Started a Food Bank Spend Their Sundays
description: The founders of EV Loves NYC, which kicked off during the pandemic, oversee the making and distribution of 2,000 meals every weekend.
content: When the pandemic caused food banks to shut down in March 2020, two soup kitchen volunteers, Mammad Mahmoodi and Sasha Allenby, borrowed a baker friend’s kitchen to make hot meals for people in need.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: In the Philippines, Blinken Vows to Strengthen Military Ties
description: Against a backdrop of rising regional tensions with China, the U.S. secretary of state reaffirmed Washington’s commitment to defending Manila.
content: MANILA — President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. of the Philippines and Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Saturday that their nations were committed to strengthening their military alliance, and that their governments would need to deal with rising tensions in Asia, including those involving China and Taiwan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Letterplay
description: Tina Labadie leads us down a beguiling path in a Sunday debut.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is one of those Sunday grids where reading Will Shortz’s print introduction before solving affects the experience. He writes: “Tina Labadie lives in London, Ontario. This is her first New York Times crossword. It has one of my favorite kinds of themes — one offering many different ‘ahas.’ The example at 118-Across, at the bottom of the puzzle, is a little different from the others, like the kicker of a joke. As a construction fillip, every letter in the alphabet is used at least once in the completed grid.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers
title: In Turbulent Times, Xi Builds a Security Fortress for China, and Himself
description: Taiwan, Covid, “color revolutions,” the classroom: everywhere, China’s leader sees threats that foreign forces can exploit, and he has enlisted the whole nation to defend against them.
content: Over informal, private meals with American leaders, China’s Xi Jinping let his guard down a little. It was a decade ago, relations were less strained, and Mr. Xi, still cementing his power, hinted he worried about the Chinese Communist Party’s grip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: How Can I Add My Partner to a Rent-Stabilized Lease?
description: The law makes it possible for relatives and domestic partners to be added to leases. But there are some hoops to jump through.
content: Q: My partner and I both are senior citizens. We have decided to live together in my rent-stabilized New York apartment, where I currently live alone. I want to know: If something happens to me as the tenant of record, will he be able to stay in the apartment? We are considering registering as domestic partners. Would this help in an effort to get him added to the lease as an additional tenant of record?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas, Ana Lankes and Sebastián López Brach
title: Think 9% Inflation Is Bad? Try 90%.
description: With the world grappling with rising prices, a tour through Argentina reveals that years of inflation can give rise to a truly bizarre economy.
content: BUENOS AIRES — Eduardo Rabuffetti is an Argentine who has been to the United States once, his 1999 honeymoon in Miami. Yet he probably knows the $100 bill better than most Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: After Chadwick Boseman’s Iconic Black Panther, Should King T’Challa Be Recast?
description: The #RecastTChalla movement argues that many white superheroes have been recast again and again — and that the King of Wakanda’s adventures shouldn’t end.
content: The actor Chadwick Boseman’s death, from cancer in August 2020, was a breathtaking shock. With his performance as Marvel’s Black Panther, Mr. Boseman became a towering figure, particularly for Black people who rarely get to see ourselves depicted as heroes on the screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Baseball Buys In on the Digital Age. But at What Cost?
description: A sport that struggles with change has mixed opinions about PitchCom and other new technologies. But everyone seems to agree that the systems work.
content: Baseball and technology have always made for wary partners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edith Cooper
title: Don’t Return to the Office for Your Boss. Go Back for Yourself.
description: Many offices are desolate, open plan landscapes dotted with individuals staring at screens, headphones on. It doesn’t have to be that way.
content: In the conversation about returning to in-person office work, it sometimes seems like bosses and workers are operating in different realities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Why Australia’s Climate Bill Matters
description: After years of inaction, the world’s third largest exporter of fossil fuels decides to get serious about global warming
content: CANBERRA, Australia — For as long as I’ve been in Australia, climate change policy has stymied governments, leading to division, inaction and embarrassment, most recently as the country became a global laggard at last year’s international climate conference in Copenhagen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: An Afrocentric Fashion Boom in the Streets and Presidential Palace
description: The wardrobe of Francia Márquez, Colombia’s first Black vice president, is the creation of a young designer at the center of an Afro-Colombian fashion explosion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Parkland Trial, Families Lay Bare Shattered Lives and Anguish
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 6, 2022
content: “I have a box over my heart with a lid so tightly closed, trying to keep all my emotions under control. But today, I’m taking the lid off that box.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: Officials Wrestle With Whether to Allow New Monkeypox Vaccination Strategy
description: A new way of injecting monkeypox vaccine could stretch the nation’s supply of shots, but some experts argue that the approach has not been sufficiently studied.
content: WASHINGTON — It sounded like a simple solution to the shortage of monkeypox vaccine: Merely by changing the way doses are injected, the federal government could vaccinate five times as many people with the supply it has in hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saskia Solomon
title: From ‘Tower of Terror’ to Brutalist Icon: A London Landmark Abides
description: Residents of Trellick Tower, a 1972 public housing block, fought to stop a development project they said would undermine the building’s integrity. But they fear the reprieve might be only temporary.
content: LONDON — When Barbara Heksel and her family moved into Trellick Tower in 1981, their friends thought they were crazy. Known for its uncompromising Brutalist design and the crime in its brooding concrete hallways, the London public housing project, built in 1972, had earned the tabloid nickname “Tower of Terror.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Swarns
title: The Search for a Meaningful Clue to the Mystery of an Enslaved Ancestor
description: Old newspaper ads are serving as a window into the hopes and histories of hundreds of individuals who were newly emancipated.
content: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lora Kelley
title: Major Indiana Employers Criticize State’s New Abortion Law
description: The drug company Eli Lilly said it “will be forced” to look outside the state for employment growth. The engine maker Cummins said the law will “impede our ability to attract and retain top talent.”
content: On Friday, the governor of Indiana signed into law a near-total abortion ban, making the state the first to approve sweeping new restrictions since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Dan Newhouse, who voted to impeach Trump, wins his primary in Washington.
description: Mr. Newhouse beat back multiple right-wing challengers, including Loren Culp, who was endorsed by the former president.
content: Representative Dan Newhouse of Washington, one of 10 House Republicans who voted to impeach President Donald J. Trump for inciting the Jan. 6 Capitol attack, will advance to the November general election to seek a fifth term after finishing in the top two in a crowded primary, according to The Associated Press. He will face Doug White, a Democratic businessman, who narrowly trailed him as of Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalley Huang and Cade Metz
title: California Regulator Accuses Tesla of Falsely Advertising Autopilot
description: A state agency said the electric carmaker had misled the public in describing its driver-assistance service as autonomous.
content: California’s Department of Motor Vehicles has accused Tesla of falsely advertising its driver-assistance technology in two complaints that could affect the company’s ability to sell cars in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Sid Jacobson, Comic Book Writer With Range, Dies at 92
description: His portfolio included the adventures of Richie Rich and graphic treatments of 9/11 and torture by the C.I.A. He also wrote dozens of songs.
content: Sid Jacobson, a veteran comic book writer and editor whose work took him from the opulent, fanciful world of Richie Rich to the real-life terrorist attacks of 9/11, died on July 23 in San Francisco. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Republicans Should Pay a Political Price for Abortion Bans
description: Kansas voters point the way for Democrats.
content: The right to an abortion is protected in the Kansas State Constitution and on Tuesday, a decisive majority of voters kept it there. Fifty-nine percent of Kansans who went to the polls voted to reject a constitutional amendment that would have opened the door to full abortion bans of the kind that exist in neighboring states like Missouri and Oklahoma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Ukrainian Grandmaster Bids to Unseat Russian Head of World Chess Body
description: Hoping to end Russia’s domination of the International Chess Federation, Andrii Baryshpolets is running for the presidency of the powerful governing organization.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Russia’s war against Ukraine has permeated even the seemingly sedate world of chess, where a Ukrainian grandmaster is bidding to unseat the powerful Russian president of the International Chess Federation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman
title: Indiana Governor Signs First Post-Roe Abortion Ban, With Limited Exceptions
description: The law passed despite dividing Republicans. Some of them said the measure was too restrictive; others objected to limited exceptions for rape and incest.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — Indiana lawmakers passed and the governor signed a near-total ban on abortion on Friday, overcoming division among Republicans and protests from Democrats to become the first state to draw up and approve sweeping new limits on the procedure since Roe v. Wade was struck down in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Photographer Who Has Always Worked on a Large Scale Goes Even Bigger
description: Edward Burtynsky has turned his 40 years spent documenting humanity’s effects on the planet into a multimedia show.
content: Long before the climate crisis was the focus of global concern Canadian photographer Edward Burtynsky was traveling the world documenting what people have inflicted on the environment and, by extension themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Democrats Eye a Major Shift in How Corporations Are Taxed
description: With a new corporate minimum tax, Democrats would be adding complexity to an already byzantine tax system.
content: WASHINGTON — At the center of the new climate and tax package that Democrats appear to be on the verge of passing is one of the most significant changes to America’s tax code in decades: a new corporate minimum tax that could reshape how the federal government collects revenue and alter how the nation’s most profitable companies invest in their businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Tests Negative for Coronavirus but Remains in Isolation
description: The negative test came a week after his rebound case emerged. He plans to travel to Rehoboth Beach in Delaware on Sunday if he tests negative for a second straight day.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden finally tested negative for the coronavirus on Saturday, a week after his rebound case emerged, but the White House physician said the president would remain in isolation “in an abundance of caution” until a second negative test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan and Erica Ackerberg
title: For Instant Happiness, Grab a Book and Head Outside
description: Photographers from The New York Times visited beaches, parks and cafes to capture readers indulging in a timeless pleasure.
content: Enjoying a book alfresco is one of summer’s simple, iconic joys, right up there with running through a sprinkler, spotting the evening’s first firefly or scraping a flat wooden spoon across a freezer-burned cup of Italian ice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Archie Battersbee, Gravely Ill 12-Year-Old, Dies After Removal of Life Support
description: The boy’s family had made several legal appeals to keep him on a ventilator, but judges in Britain sided with doctors in finding that he had no hope of recovery.
content: LONDON — Archie Battersbee, a 12-year-old British boy whose life support was withdrawn after a legal battle between his parents and his doctors, died on Saturday, bringing to an end another wrenching case over who makes life and death decisions for a seriously ill child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Alabama City Moves to Dissolve Police Department Over Racist Text
description: Leaders of Vincent, Ala., suspended the chief and assistant police chief after a screenshot circulated on social media showing the text message.
content: A small city in Alabama moved this week to disband its three-member police force after one of them sent a racist text message that then circulated on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: There’s Just One Drug to Treat Monkeypox. Good Luck Getting It.
description: Doctors who want to prescribe tecovirimat, or Tpoxx, must navigate a gantlet of bureaucratic hurdles that experts say could be quickly lifted.
content: The only drug available to treat monkeypox is so difficult to access that just a fraction of the nearly 7,000 patients in the United States have been given it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: In Senate Battle, Democrats Defy Biden’s Low Standing (for Now)
description: “The billion-dollar question,” as one Republican pollster put it, is whether Democratic candidates in crucial Senate races can continue to outpace the president’s unpopularity.
content: PHOENIX — In a Senate split 50-50, Democrats on the campaign trail and in Congress have zero margin for error as the party tries to navigate a hostile political environment defined chiefly by President Biden’s albatross-like approval ratings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
title: Israel-Gaza Fighting Flares for a Second Day
description: The sudden spurt of violence since Friday is the worst in more than a year in the crowded, impoverished territory. The two-day death toll in Gaza rose to more than 20 and included a militant leader.
content: The most violent conflagration in more than a year between Israel and Gaza militants extended into a second day on Saturday, with exchanges of rocket fire and airstrikes that destroyed residential buildings, and pushed the death toll to at least 24, according to Palestinian health officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Reading Outdoors
description: Grab a book and read outside this weekend, if you can. Here’s some inspiration.
content: What is the best setup for serious outdoor reading? I propose it’s in a chair, sitting upright, in the shade of a tree or umbrella, comfortable but not too comfortable. A beach towel or picnic blanket works, but the sun moves, your back or neck gets stiff, it’s not a sure thing. My friend Avi insists you need to be in one of those zero-gravity recliners that I’m positive would function as an adult cradle and instantly lull me to sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Don’t Expect Alex Jones’s Comeuppance to Stop Lies
description: His success has inspired a new generation of conspiracy theorists, who have learned how to stay away from legal trouble.
content: If it hadn’t been so excruciatingly sad, Alex Jones’s defamation trial might have been cathartic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Drop Box for Babies: Conservatives Promote a Way to Give Up Newborns Anonymously
description: After Roe, groups are seeking to expand safe haven laws, which allow women to surrender babies with minimal interference. But these laws pose their own problems.
content: The Safe Haven Baby Box at a firehouse in Carmel, Ind., looked like a library book drop. It had been available for three years for anyone who wanted to surrender a baby anonymously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: Graywolf Press’s New Publisher is Looking for Talent in New Places
description: Carmen Giménez, Graywolf’s new executive director, wants to search for writers wherever “people are talking or thinking, or being creative or having a voice.”
content: When Carmen Giménez, then a young poet in San Francisco’s vibrant literary scene, walked into one of the city’s bookstores in 1999, she was dazzled by its selection of chapbooks: short and often handmade, the booklets came in all sizes, textures, and materials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The New Politics of Abortion
description: The pro-life movement needs to learn the art of the possible.
content: Some liberals seemed genuinely surprised by the results of the Kansas referendum on abortion. A reliably Republican state, a sweeping pro-choice victory. Who could have foreseen it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ava Sasani and Vimal Patel
title: Killings of Three Muslim Men in Albuquerque May Be Linked, Police Say
description: The authorities also suspect the deaths could be connected to the homicide of a Muslim man in 2021.
content: The police in Albuquerque are investigating the killings of three Muslim men that they say may be connected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The U.S. Relationship With China Does Not Need to Be So Tense
description: Tensions over Taiwan underscore the need for the United States to engage more deeply with China on more than just trade.
content: China, economically ascendant, has become increasingly assertive in pressing its economic, political and territorial claims. The United States, which long treated the country as something of a charity case, now regards it as a rival and, increasingly, as a threat. While some tension is inevitable, the rhetoric in both nations has taken a bellicose turn. There is little trust or cooperation even on issues of clear mutual interest, like combating the Covid-19 pandemic or addressing climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: City’s Admissions That It Can’t Care for Rikers Detainees May Propel Suits
description: The family of Herman Diaz, who choked to death on an orange, filed the first case relying on the documents. Dozens more may follow.
content: The security-camera images tell a remarkable story: A man being held on Rikers Island collapses and is carried to a medical clinic — not by the correction officer outside his housing unit but by other detainees. The man, Herman Diaz, 52, who had choked on an orange slice, did not survive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Chinese Military Drills Aim to Awe, Both Abroad and at Home
description: As China staged its third day of war exercises, state media was also working hard to shape the narrative, in what seemed a response to earlier public discontent.
content: China’s military continued on Saturday to menace Taiwan with a series of drills, a show of force intended not only to intimidate Taiwan and the United States, but also to appease a domestic audience that had seemed disappointed by what it perceived as an insufficiently bellicose posture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Berk
title: Would You Go Back to the Office for an Eames Chair?
description: Ben Watson is overseeing the merger of Herman Miller and Knoll, with the belief that good design means good business.
content: Ben Watson was in his happy place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Fighting Around Ukrainian Nuclear Plant Heightens Safety Fears
description: A series of blasts Friday at the plant, which the Russian military is using as cover for artillery attacks, renewed concerns of a radiation catastrophe.
content: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine —  Fighting raged on Saturday near a sprawling nuclear power plant in the south of Ukraine, despite warnings from nuclear safety watchdogs earlier this week that conditions there were posing risks and “out of control.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Furor Over Documenta Highlights a Widening Chasm in Germany
description: One of the art world’s most important events, Documenta, is at its halfway point. So far, a tiny fraction of the art has been the main topic of conversation.
content: Documenta, an art world mega-event held every five years in Kassel, Germany, is no stranger to controversy. Yet this year’s edition has ‌eclipsed anything in the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: The Companies That Take Money Straight From Your Paycheck
description: Some lenders and retailers have a pretty neat business model: You pay them before your wages ever hit your bank account. And sometimes they give you no choice.
content: At any given time, millions of workers are overdue on at least one bill. But it is the rare employer that is late in cutting its paychecks or that bounces them altogether.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: How This Economic Moment Rewrites the Rules
description: Jobs aplenty. Sizzling demand. If the United States is headed into a recession, it is taking an unusual route, with many markers of a boom.
content: To understand the strange, conflicting signals being sent by the U.S. economy right now, it helps to look at Williston, N.D., in about 2010.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Boushnak
title: A Time for War, a Time for Play
description: Summer for Ukraine’s children means sunshine and swimming, but also long hours in bomb shelters and mine-safety training. A photographer captured their days in Kyiv for The New York Times.
content: A late-July morning, and the sounds of the summer camp were the sounds of summer camps everywhere as children raced from activity to activity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Raúl Vilchis
title: Seeking Asylum in Texas; Sent to New York to Make a Political Point
description: Gov. Greg Abbott chartered a bus to send a group of migrants to New York, where Mayor Eric Adams said asylum seekers were overwhelming the city’s homeless shelters.
content: The first 3,500 miles of Jose Rodríguez’s journey from Venezuela to New York took nearly two months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson, Tiffany Hsu and Michael Levenson
title: Jury Orders Alex Jones to Pay $45.2 Million in Sandy Hook Case
description: The parents of a child killed in the school shooting were awarded the punitive damages at the conclusion of the defamation trial against the conspiracy theorist.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — A Texas jury ordered the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones on Friday to pay the parents of a child killed in the 2012 Sandy Hook school shooting $45.2 million in punitive damages for spreading the lie that they helped stage the massacre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Climate and Tax Bill Scales Crucial Senate Hurdle, Paving Path to Passage
description: Democrats united behind the plan and advanced it over unanimous Republican opposition, signaling that they had finally coalesced behind a bill that could become law within days.
content: WASHINGTON — A divided Senate took a crucial step on Saturday toward approving Democrats’ plan to tackle climate change, bring down health care costs and raise taxes on large corporations, with a test vote that paved the way to enact a significant piece of President Biden’s domestic agenda in the coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carolyn Wilke
title: Dolphin Strangers Met in the Bahamas. Things Went Swimmingly.
description: Two research teams found that dolphins could forge strong social bonds with outsiders within a few years
content: In 2013, a group of 52 Atlantic spotted dolphins, driven to migrate by unknown forces, left their home on the Little Bahama Bank in the northern Bahamas. They traveled 100 miles south to the island chain of Bimini, a destination already inhabited by a community of 120 Atlantic spotted dolphins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: Breonna Taylor Raid Puts Focus on Officers Who Lie for Search Warrants
description: When warrants are based on misstated evidence or outright lies, the consequences can be disastrous. Prosecutors say that’s what happened in Ms. Taylor’s case.
content: On the day before police officers shot and killed Breonna Taylor in her apartment in Louisville, Ky., a detective tried to persuade a judge that a former boyfriend of Ms. Taylor’s could be using her home to stash money and drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Augustin and Oscar Lopez
title: Fire at Cuban Oil Facility Leaves Dozens Injured, Hundreds Evacuated
description: Six-hundred people have been evacuated after an oil storage tank base caught fire in the western Matanzas Province.
content: HAVANA — Lightning struck a crude oil storage facility on the northern coast of Cuba, igniting a fire that on Saturday had left dozens of people injured, 17 firefighters missing and prompted the evacuation of some 600 people, according to the authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: After 246 Years, Marine Corps Gives 4 Stars to a Black Officer
description: Gen. Michael E. Langley is the first Black person to attain the highest rank in the corps, whose most senior leadership had until now consisted entirely of white men.
content: WASHINGTON — In the military, there have already been countless promotion ceremonies this year, held on Army bases, aircraft carriers and even, in one case, an escarpment overlooking Omaha Beach in Normandy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Edgar Sandoval, Emily Rhyne, Tamir Kalifa and Callaghan O'Hare
title: The Excruciating Echo of Grief in Uvalde
description: Uvalde, Texas, buried 21 people after the Robb Elementary School massacre. The community’s anguish has been compounded by anger over the police response; many have turned to activism.
content: Uvalde, Texas, buried 21 people after the Robb Elementary School massacre. The community’s anguish has been compounded by anger over the police response; many have turned to activism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Davis
title: Winds of Change
description: Helping my son feel safe in a scary world.
content: Helping my son feel safe in a scary world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Israel Strikes Gaza for Second Day Straight
description: Israeli airstrikes destroyed residential buildings in Gaza and killed several people, according to Palestinian health officials. The Israeli military described the buildings as weapons stores belonging to militant operatives and said evacuations took place before the strikes.
content: Israeli airstrikes destroyed residential buildings in Gaza and killed several people, according to Palestinian health officials. The Israeli military described the buildings as weapons stores belonging to militant operatives and said evacuations took place before the strikes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is Homework Necessary for Student Success?
description: Readers argue both sides, citing Finland, the value of repetition, education inequity and more.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 6, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 6, 2022.
content: An article on Page 9 this weekend about six podcasts about political scandals and upheaval refers incorrectly to the producers of “The Fault Line: Bush, Blair and Iraq.” They are Somethin’ Else and Sony Music Entertainment, not the BBC.
source.name: The New York Times
